history.content:
If you have experience doing proofs and are well-acquainted with proof techniques, you'll be fine (given that you have already taken a discrete math course). Be aware though that 170 is a challenging and time-consuming class regardless.

----------------------------------

If you are a transfer and you don't have a class that articulates for CS 70, you are going to have to take CS 70 anyway as it is a graduation requirement (assuming you are CS/EECS). I'm in a similar situation (have taken a discrete math class before transferring) but CS 70 cover way more topics and in more depth compared to the CC class. In my opinion, it wouldn't make sense to take CS 70 after CS 170, especially if you are interested in theory.

If you have experience doing proofs and are well-acquainted with proof techniques, you'll be fine (given that you have already taken a discrete math course). Be aware though that 170 is a challenging and time-consuming class regardless.

I am a junior transfer student, and I am currently taking 61A, 61B, 16A. I know CS 170 is one of the most useful courses for job interviews and theory research, so I really want to take it ASAP. I am getting A+/A in 61B with Hilfinger this semester, and I have taken a discrete math course in my community college, which covers induction and graph theory. Is it okay for me to skip CS70 and take CS170 next semester? Thank you!
history.subject: Taking 170 without 70
